awd_abstract_narration:
A doughnut-shaped surface, perhaps with more than one hole - or none at all, can be cut into triangles, and if we record how the cuts were done, we can put the surface back together by gluing. Alternatively, we can create a dual surface, where we make new triangles with a vertex for each of the original ones, and sides corresponding to the touching data of the original triangles. Poincaré's amazing theorem from 1895 tells us that the dual shape is deformable to the original, regardless of the way cuts were done. Since its discovery, this duality result has been improved on and generalized in many different areas of mathematics. In homotopy theory one not only studies objects up to deformations, but also keeps track of deformations between them as well as coherence data, all in a streamlined way. Along with its recent augmentation into derived algebraic geometry, homotopy theory has become a unifying ground for numerous mathematical concepts, including duality.  


The PI will work with her collaborators to explore two duality contexts in which homotopical and arithmetic information are intertwined. One of those involves establishing a homotopical extension of a classical result of Poitou and Tate about duality in the cohomology of number fields, as well as investigating the implications of such an extension to questions in arithmetic. The other involves understanding duality for some of the basic objects in so-called chromatic homotopy theory, whereby one organizes structural and computational information in homotopy according to periodicity properties. This would be a homotopical enhancement of a cohomological duality property of the chromatic Galois groups known as Morava stabilizer groups, and is based on seminal work of Gross and Hopkins. Both of these project goals may involve further developing the foundations for profinite group actions on profinite objects.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In homotopy theory, we study geometric phenomena which are invariant under continuous deformations. Because of the abundance of deformations, there is generally no way to specify homotopical information as a concrete finite set of data. Instead, an object is studied by probing it via circles and higher-dimensional spheres, giving rise to the homotopy groups of said object. Studying these groups has been the driving force behind many developments in homotopy theory for the entire history of this field. Since the 1980s, it has been understood that a deep hierarchy of homotopical properties exists, which is exhibited as periodic phenomena in homotopy groups, and is indexed by a pair of a prime number p and an integer n known as the height. This is known as chromatic homotopy theory.

 

The main goals of the research sponsored by this grant were to study notions of symmetry in chromatic homotopy theory, known as duality and invertibility. 

 

In the context of duality, a stronger relationship was found between a chromatic notion of duality at height n and the algebraic notion of Serre and Lazard's classical duality for certain compact p-adic analytic groups of dimension equaling the square of n. This sheds new light on and gives meaning to certain self-dual phenomena that were previously only observed through computations.

 

In the closely related context of invertibility, several computational and theoretical advances were made. The main objects of study were Picard groups, which classify invertible objects, and Brauer groups, which are a categorification of Picard groups. In the process of systematically computing Picard groups, a discovery was made of an unexpected invertible module over a chromatic spectrum at height 2 and the prime 2, related to number theory as well. This was the first indication that the representation theory of certain symmetry groups must be taken into account when classifying these objects. That idea has been fruitful in other branches of this project, and in particular was crucial in the ultimate determination of the exotic Picard group of the chromatic category at height 2 and the prime 2.

 

Last but not least, we found that determining Brauer groups can be more efficiently done if small algebraic perturbations are taken into account when computing Picard groups, resulting in Picard sheaves. Using this idea and a mix of arithmetic geometry and homotopy theory, we found that the Brauer group of topological modular forms is an infinitely-generated torsion group.

 

This grant provided financial support for 2 PhD students as research assistants. With the support of this grant, Stojanoska mentored several graduate students, and supervised undergraduate research involving 12 students over a period of 2 years.
